Lewis Carroll: What the Tortoise Said to Achilles

Gene Callahan

Abstract

Lewis Carroll is most famous, of course, for his Alice books: Alice in Wonderland and Alice Through the Looking Glass. Those works certainly display an anti-rationalist spirit, and we will explore them in this essay. However, Carroll, in his other life, was the Oxford mathematician and logician Charles Dodgson, and besides making important technical contributions to those fields, he also gave serious thought to their philosophical foundations.

Those reflections are expressed most succinctly in his essay "What the Tortoise Said to Achilles," which was published in the philosophical journal Mind. At a time when formalism was on the rise in both mathematics and logic, Carroll wrote his essay to demonstrate that such formalism could never capture the essential truth of logic itself: there are an infinite number of possible formal systems of logic, and there is no formalism that can help us to decide between them without an infinite regress. In choosing one formal system as preferable to another, we must of necessity rely upon our own sense of truth (and here we see an anticipation of Michael Polanyi's Personal Knowledge), and not another formalism. As the Wittgensteinian philosopher Peter Winch wrote in The Idea of a Social Science and its Relation to Philosophy (1958), Carroll showed that "the actual process of drawing an inference, which is after all at the heart of logic, is something which cannot be represented as a logical formula ... Learning to infer is not just a matter of being taught about explicit logical relations between propositions; it is learning to do something" (p. 57).

When we fully understand Carroll's point in the tortoise and Achilles essay, we see that he was a forerunner of both Gödel and Wittgenstein in pointing out how any formal system must be anchored in some deeper notion of its significance for it to have any relevance to truth.
